text: Hey everyone! Monday morning ask for you all... How do I ask about value for money in a survey!? I'm thinking about whether the building they received was good value for money basically! But need it better phrased than that

elements.text: Hey everyone! Monday morning ask for you all... How do I ask about value for money in a survey!? I'm thinking about whether the building they received was good value for money basically! But need it better phrased than that

text:
I really do think that with the current content marketing context and just the way the SERP looks, we should start prioritizing thought leadership more.

What does that look like and how do you make it fit in your current marketing strategy?

- Start by naming your brand ambassadors. Your internal stakeholders are a perfect option if you're just launching and haven't built a community yet.
- Make it a regular thing. Practice daily communication and get as many experts on your team on board as possible.
- Find a pattern that works and iterate on it.
- Analyze your target market and don't be afraid to ask them directly about what they'd want to see, hear, read, feel, etc. Find out where they access content frequently, what they're searching for, whom they trust, and more.
- When your budget allows, partner with external industry leaders to create content and reach out to their own network.
- Offer your team the resources they need to keep developing their skills, attend events, and become members of industry groups.
- Don't force your experts onto multiple platforms at once. Have each person focus on 1-2 channels that provide the most engagement for them.
- Do things differently. Want to position your tool as a category leader? You'll need to either innovate when it comes to your product or take your marketing to the next level. Find a content format, report, video series, or whatever else your competition hasn't yet experimented with and own it.
- Don't forget about knowledge management. Ideally, in the event that a team member leaves, you'll want someone else to take over just where they left.
- Keep your business objectives in mind at all times. Stay relevant and avoid providing "too much value" in exchange for vanity metrics.

More ideas to share?

text: following this! I have some ideas but would love to hear from someone with more experience. For the content part, isn't it largely based on feedback/collab with your partner? I've been mostly brainstorming with the partner on what the best content would be for them. After all, some companies just have super different needs.

elements.text: following this! I have some ideas but would love to hear from someone with more experience. For the content part, isn't it largely based on feedback/collab with your partner? I've been mostly brainstorming with the partner on what the best content would be for them. After all, some companies just have super different needs.

text: These are all great points. I'd add: *repurpose content*.

elements.text: These are all great points. I'd add:

text: We're a marketing agency and have developed partner and alliance sales enablement content for a number of clients.  It really is going to depend up on the nature of the partner relationship you have and what you are trying to convey to your target audience/joint customers.
